SENT.plain: The effects of acute hyperglycaemia and streptozotocin-induced diabetes on infarct size were measured 48 h after middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO) in Fischer 344 rats
Both hyperglycaemia (+46%) and diabetes (+68%) increased infarct volume when compared to normoglycaemic rats
Insulin-treated diabetic rats exhibited an infarct size similar to that observed in normoglycaemic rats
Neuroprotection has been difficult to demonstrate in pathological conditions that increase infarct volume such as chronic arterial hypertension
However, administration of the non-competitive NMDA antagonist, dizocilpine (MK-801), after MCAO, reduced the volume of ischaemic damage (by 33-48%) in all groups

The present findings indicate (a) that the detrimental effects of experimental diabetes on infarct volume are largely attributed to hyperglycaemia; and (b) dizocilpine was as neuroprotective in hyperglycaemia and diabetic conditions as in normoglycaemic rats
